FedMeS: Personalized Federated Continual Learning Leveraging Local Memory

Jin Xie1, Chenqing Zhu1, and Songze Li2

1The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (Guangzhou)

2Southeast University

â€ â€ footnotetext:
Â Regular Paper

Abstract â€ƒWe focus on the problem of Personalized Federated Continual Learning (PFCL): a group of distributed clients, each with a sequence of local tasks on arbitrary data distributions, collaborate through a central server to train a personalized model at each client, with the model expected to achieve good performance on all local tasks. We propose a novel PFCL framework called Federated Memory Strengthening (FedMeS) to address the challenges of client drift and catastrophic forgetting. In FedMeS, each client stores samples from previous tasks using a small amount of local memory, and leverages this information to both 1) calibrate gradient updates in training process; and 2) perform KNN-based Gaussian inference to facilitate personalization. FedMeS is designed to be task-oblivious, such that the same inference process is applied to samples from all tasks to achieve good performance. FedMeS is analyzed theoretically and evaluated experimentally. It is shown to outperform all baselines in average accuracy and forgetting rate, over various combinations of datasets, task distributions, and client numbers.

Keywords â€ƒFederated Learning, Continual Learning, Personalization, Memory

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) [1] is an emerging distributed learning framework that allows for collaborative training of a model across multiple clients while keeping their raw data locally stored. A typical FL process involves local training on each client and global model aggregation on a cloud server, with only model updates or gradients being shared between clients and the server.

Data collected from different clients in an FL system often have drastically different distributions. As seen in Figure Fig.Â 1(a), this can lead to model parameter divergence and client drift [2], causing potentially poor performance for certain clients. The conventional way of training a single model is insufficient to fit all the non-IID data, and a personalized model needs to be trained for each participating clientÂ [3, 4], which is known as personalized FL.

Another key characteristic in real-world FL systems is that clients are continuously collecting new data (new task) which may exhibit different distributions from previous local data (tasks). Hence, it would be preferable to train a local model that is able to achieve consistently good performance in all local tasks. In an FL system, the problem is solved by federated continual learning (FCL) [5, 6, 7]. The phenomenon of a model failing to perform well on previously trained tasks is called catastrophic forgetting [8], which is illustrated in Fig.Â 1(b).

In practical FL systems, the data and task heterogeneity often exist both across clients and over time on a single client. For instance, as shown in Fig.Â 1(c), in a IIoT scenario, multiple factories manufacturing different products would like to use FL for training defect detection models collaboratively. Other than the difference between the types of products, each factory may experience change of tasks over time due to e.g., change of recipe and upgrade of the production line. Aiming to address the challenges of client drift and catastrophic forgetting simultaneously, in the paper we focus on the personalized federated continual learning (PFCL) problem. In a PFCL system, each client observes a stream of arbitrarily different tasks, and would like to collaborate through the server to train a personalized model, which performs well on both previous and current local tasks.

There have been prior attempts at tackling the FCL problem, like FedWeIT [7], where task-generic and task-specific knowledge are shared across clients to decompose the model parameters. However, as demonstrated in [2], FedWeIT struggles to handle the issue of client drift caused by data heterogeneity and has poor scalability as the number of tasks increases.

In this paper, we propose a novel PFCL framework called Federated Memory Strengthening (FedMeS). FedMeS utilizes small amount of local memory at each client to store information about previous tasks, and leverage this memory to assist both the training and inference processes. During training process, the gradients are constantly calibrated against the data samples from previous tasks to avoid catastrophic forgetting. A newly designed regularization term scaled by a loss-based parameter is used to facilitate the training of personalized models, using information from the global model. In the inference process, FedMeS further leverages the memory information to perform KNN-based Gaussian inference, further strengthening the modelâ€™s personalization capability. Moreover, FedMeS exhibits a major advantage of being task-oblivious, meaning that the inference processes for test samples from all tasks are identical, and all are expected to achieve high performance.

We theoretically characterize the convergence of FedMeS, and empirically evaluate its performance over various dataset combinations, task constructions, task distributions, and client numbers. Over all experiments, FedMeS uniformly outperforms all baselines in terms of accuracy metrics and forgetting rate. Performance of FedMeS under different memory sizes and its execution times are also experimentally investigated.

2 Related Work

Personalized Federated Learning. A simple idea is by deploying a global model and fine tuning parameters through gradient descent on local clients [9, 10, 11]. Meta-learning based FL methods realize model personalization through hyperparameters [12]. PerKNN [13] is a special case, where embeddings of training samples are stored for local memorization for KNN-based Gaussian inference. The mainstream design is to interpolate a global model and one local model per client, and the task-specific models are learned both globally and locally [14, 15]. Below are some methods adopting this design. Regularization terms on proximal models help construct personalized information [16, 17]. Sometimes an initialized model or regularizer-based learnable bases are constructed for each client [3]. In other cases, multiple global models are trained at the server, and task-specific regularization terms force similar tasks to be close, making the training on heterogeneous clients more accurate [18, 19].

Continual Learning. Memory replay methods are widely used in continual learning (CL) to maintain prediction accuracies of past tasks. Generally speaking, a memory buffer is used to store previous data which are replayed while learning a new task to alleviate forgetting [20, 21]. Experience replay (ER) jointly optimizes the network parameters by interleaving the previous task exemplars with current task data [22, 23]. An alternative solution is by constrained optimization. GEM [24] and A-GEM [25] leverage episodic memory to compute previous task gradients to constrain the current update step. Pesudo Rehearsal [26] is used in early works with shallow neural networks. Generative-based methods [27] synthesize previous data produced by generative models and replay the synthesized data. Besides replay methods, regularization-based methods [28, 29] and parameter isolation methods [30] have also been proposed for CL.

Although a lot of work has been done in CL, just a few works have tried to use CL in a federated setting. FedWeIT [7] is a typical one, where task-generic and task-specific knowledge are shared across clients to decompose the model parameters. However, as demonstrated in [2], FedWeIT struggles to handle the issue of client drift caused by data heterogeneity and does not address the scalability of tasks. Other methods, like LFedCon2 [31], use traditional classifiers instead of DNN and propose an algorithm dealing with a concept drift based on ensemble retraining. FLwF and FLwF-2T [32] use a distillation-based approach dealing with catastrophic forgetting in FL scenario and focus on the class-incremental learning scenario.

3 Problem Definition

We consider an FL system that consists of nğ‘›n clients and a central server. Over time, each client kğ‘˜k (k=1,â€¦,nğ‘˜1â€¦ğ‘›k=1,\ldots,n) continually collects private datasets from a sequence of Tğ‘‡T machine learning tasks. The conventional FL problem corresponds to a single-task scenario. For a particular task tğ‘¡t, the following objective function is optimized over the global model ğ°ğ°\mathbf{w}:

In the general case of evolving tasks, each client intends to obtain a personalized model which maintains good performance on all its previous tasks. Motivated by this need, we incorporate the concept of continual learning and into a personalized FL framework, and formally define the personalized federated continual learning (PFCL) problem below. The last constraint ensures that the new model obtained from task tğ‘¡t has a lower loss than the old model over previous datasets, effectively alleviating the forgetting of previous tasks.

4 The Proposed FedMeS Framework

We propose an algorithm, Federated Memory Strengthening (FedMeS), to solve the PFCL problem defined in (2). The key idea of FedMeS is to design local memory data samples from previous tasks, and flexibly use them in both training and inference processes. In training process, the local memory is used for gradient correction to avoid catastrophic forgetting; in inference process, a KNN algorithm based on the representations of local samples helps to improve the accuracy of the personalized model. The overall workflow of FedMeS is illustrated in FigureÂ 2, and pseudocode is given in AlgorithmÂ 1.

4.2 Training Process of FedMeS

The training of task tğ‘¡t (t=1,â€¦,Tğ‘¡1â€¦ğ‘‡t=1,\ldots,T) proceeds over multiple global iterations between the server and the clients. In each global iteration, the server broadcasts the global model ğ°ğ°\mathbf{w} to the clients, waits for clients to upload personalized models wktsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡w_{k}^{t}, and aggregates them to update the global model ğ°â†1nâ€‹âˆ‘k=1nwktâ†ğ°1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\mathbf{w}\leftarrow\frac{1}{n}\sum_{k=1}^{n}w_{k}^{t}.

During local training process, each client kğ‘˜k runs multiple local iterations to update wktsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡w_{k}^{t}. In each local iteration, client kğ‘˜k starts with the global model ğ°ğ°\mathbf{w} and perform SGD according to the objective in (2) to update wktsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡w_{k}^{t}. The model update for each mini-batch is different according to whether the condition (3) is satisfied. For a better compatibility with running SGD, we alternatively consider the following condition on the inner product of current gradients on current and previous tasks:

âŸ¨âˆ‡â„’â€‹(wkt;ğ’Ÿkt),âˆ‡â„’â€‹(wkt;â„³kt)âŸ©â‰¥0,âˆ‡â„’superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘¡âˆ‡â„’superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptâ„³ğ‘˜ğ‘¡0\left\langle\nabla\mathcal{L}\left(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t}\right),\nabla\mathcal{L}\left(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t}\right)\right\rangle\geq 0, (4)

which was shown in [25] equivalent to the condition in (3).

When (4) is satisfied, it means that the updates on current task tğ‘¡t and previous tasks are roughly in the same direction, so the optimization on current task would not negatively impact the performance of past tasks. As a result, it is safe to update the model along the gradient of current task as follows, for some learning rate Î·1subscriptğœ‚1\eta_{1}:

wkt=wktâˆ’Î·1â€‹(âˆ‡â„’â€‹(wkt;ğ’Ÿkt)+Î»â€‹â€–wktâˆ’ğ°â€–).superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚1âˆ‡â„’superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğœ†normsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ°w_{k}^{t}=w_{k}^{t}-\eta_{1}\left(\nabla\mathcal{L}(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t})+\lambda\|w_{k}^{t}-\mathbf{w}\|\right). (5)

Â Â Â Remark 1.

Only one of (5) and (6) is executed in each local training iteration: gradients are updated based on the objective function in (2) only when (4) holds. Otherwise, as analytically demonstrated in SectionÂ 4.4, updating wktsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡w_{k}^{t} according to (6) multiple times allows the inner product âŸ¨âˆ‡â„’â€‹(wkt;ğ’Ÿkt),âˆ‡â„’â€‹(wkt;â„³kt)âŸ©âˆ‡â„’superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘¡âˆ‡â„’superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptâ„³ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\langle\nabla\mathcal{L}\left(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t}\right),\nabla\mathcal{L}\left(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t}\right)\rangle (currently negative) to approach and eventually exceed zero.

In FedMeS, rather than fixing the regularization parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda in (2), we propose a novel loss-based approach for dynamically adjusting Î»ğœ†\lambda, to better draw useful information from other clients through the global model to facilitate learning of local tasks. Specifically, we set the value of Î»ğœ†\lambda as:

Î»=2â‹…sigmoidâ€‹(1â„’â€‹(ğ°,ğ’Ÿkt)).ğœ†â‹…2sigmoid1â„’ğ°superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘¡\lambda=2\cdot\text{sigmoid}\left(\frac{1}{\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w},\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t})}\right). (7)

Intuitively, when â„’â€‹(ğ°,ğ’Ÿkt)â„’ğ°superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘¡\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w},\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t}) is relatively large, it means the global model ğ°ğ°\mathbf{w} performs poorly on the current task of client kğ‘˜k, and the personalized model wktsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡w_{k}^{t} should deviate from the global model by decreasing Î»ğœ†\lambda. On the other hand, a small â„’â€‹(ğ°,ğ’Ÿkt)â„’ğ°superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘¡\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w},\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t}) would encourage wktsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡w_{k}^{t} to approach the global model ğ°ğ°\mathbf{w}, which corresponds to a lager Î»ğœ†\lambda. The sigmoid function here limits Î»ğœ†\lambda within [0,2]02[0,2], following the result from [16].

(9)

Finally, the FedMeS prediction result of ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} on client kğ‘˜k is obtain by a convex combination of outputs from local personalized model and KNN inference:

FedMeSkâ€‹(ğ±)=Î¸kâ‹…bwktâ€‹(ğ±)+(1âˆ’Î¸k)â€‹hwktâ€‹(ğ±).subscriptFedMeSğ‘˜ğ±â‹…subscriptğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ±1subscriptğœƒğ‘˜subscriptâ„superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ±\mathrm{FedMeS}_{k}(\mathbf{x})=\theta_{k}\cdot b_{w_{k}^{t}}(\mathbf{x})+(1-\theta_{k})h_{w_{k}^{t}}(\mathbf{x}). (10)

Here hwktsubscriptâ„superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡h_{w_{k}^{t}} is the personalized local model parameterized by wktsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡w_{k}^{t}, and Î¸kâˆˆ(0,1)subscriptğœƒğ‘˜01\theta_{k}\in(0,1) is a combining parameter which can be tuned through local validation or cross-validation.

Â Â Â Remark 2.

As proved in [33], augmenting the model inference with a memorization mechanism (KNN in this case) helps to improve the performance. In [13], local memorization through KNN has been applied to improve the accuracies of local models in personalized FL, for a single task. FedMeS extends the application of this technique on memorization over an arbitrary sequence of tasks, via utilizing a subset of samples from each task. Also, this inference enhancement of FedMeS comes for free, as this memory is readily available from the preceeding training process.

Â Â Â Remark 3.

Another major advantage of FedMeS is that it is task-oblivious. That is, the same inference process is applied for all test samples, and no prior knowledge is needed about which task the sample belongs to. This also reflects the strong robustness of FedMeS: regardless of the original task, a good inference performance is always guaranteed by a unified FedMeS inference process. This is, however, not the case for other task-incremental learning CL methods like in [34].

4.4 Convergence Analysis

5 Experiments

5.1 Setup

Datasets and models. We select five commonly used public datasets: CIFAR-100 [35], EMINIST [36], CORe50 [37], MiniImageNet-100 [38] and TinyImageNet-200. For the purpose of PFCL evaluation, we split these datasets into multiple tasks forming four cross-class datasets: Split CIFAR-100: CIFAR-100 consists of 100 classes, we split them into 10 tasks with 10 classes each. Split EMINIST: We utilize 60 of the 62 categories in the original dataset, and split them into 10 tasks with 6 classes each. A total of 120,000 imagines are used. Split CORe50: CORe50 is specifically designed for assessing continual learning techniques and has 50 objects collected in 11 different sessions. We naturally split it into 11 tasks with 50 classes each. Split MiniImageNet: MiniImageNet-100 is commonly used in few-shot learning benchmarks, which consists of 50,000 data points and 10,000 testing points from 100 classes. We split this dataset into 10 tasks with 10 classes each.

Besides, we also design cross-domain datasets to evaluate the cross domain performance for FedMeS. Fusion Tasks-40: This benchmark combines 200,000 images from three distinct datasets: CIFAR-100, MiniImageNet-100, and TinyImageNet-200, with a total of 400 classes. These classes are then divided into 40 non-IID tasks, with each task comprising 10 disjoint classes.

We use 6-layer CNNs for the Split CIFAR-100 and Split CORe50, 2-layer CNNs for the Split EMINIST, and ResNet-18 for Split MiniImageNet and Fusion Tasks-40. For the task and dataset distributions, each client is assigned a unique task sequence, in which a subset of 2-5 classes are randomly selected for each task, with the goal of ensuring data heterogeneity.

Metrics. We consider the following performance metrics.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Average Accuracy: We consider four different average accuracies. We define the averaged accuracy of client kğ‘˜k among all learned tğ‘¡t tasks after the training of task tğ‘¡t: Ak,t=1tâ€‹âˆ‘i=1tat,iksubscriptğ´ğ‘˜ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘˜A_{k,t}=\frac{1}{t}{\textstyle\sum_{i=1}^{t}}a_{t,i}^{k} as accuracy of client kğ‘˜k at task tğ‘¡t, where at,iksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘˜a_{t,i}^{k} (i<tğ‘–ğ‘¡i<t) is the test accuracy of task iğ‘–i after the training of task tğ‘¡t in client kğ‘˜k; averaged accuracy of client kğ‘˜k after training all Tğ‘‡T tasks Aâ€‹câ€‹câ€‹_â€‹Câ€‹lâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹nâ€‹tk=1Tâ€‹âˆ‘i=1TAk,iğ´ğ‘ğ‘_ğ¶ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘’ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜1ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘‡subscriptğ´ğ‘˜ğ‘–Acc\_Client_{k}=\frac{1}{T}{\textstyle\sum_{i=1}^{T}}A_{k,i}; average accuracy among all nğ‘›n clients at tğ‘¡t-th task: Aâ€‹câ€‹câ€‹_â€‹Tâ€‹aâ€‹sâ€‹kt=1nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nAj,tğ´ğ‘ğ‘_ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘ subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¡1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘›subscriptğ´ğ‘—ğ‘¡Acc\_Task_{t}=\frac{1}{n}{\textstyle\sum_{j=1}^{n}}A_{j,t}; average accuracy among all nğ‘›n clients in all learned Tğ‘‡T tasks after completing the training process of all tasks: Aâ€‹câ€‹câ€‹_â€‹Aâ€‹Lâ€‹L=1nâ€‹1Tâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nâˆ‘i=1TAj,tğ´ğ‘ğ‘_ğ´ğ¿ğ¿1ğ‘›1ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘‡subscriptğ´ğ‘—ğ‘¡Acc\_ALL=\frac{1}{n}\frac{1}{T}{\textstyle\sum_{j=1}^{n}}{\textstyle\sum_{i=1}^{T}}A_{j,t}.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Forgetting rate: The forgetting rate Ftksuperscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘¡ğ‘˜F_{t}^{k} of client kğ‘˜k at tğ‘¡t-th task is defined as Ftk=1tâˆ’1â€‹âˆ‘i=1tâˆ’1maxjâˆˆ{1,â€¦,tâˆ’1}â¡(aj,ikâˆ’at,ik)superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘¡ğ‘˜1ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘—1â€¦ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘˜F_{t}^{k}=\frac{1}{t-1}{\textstyle\sum_{i=1}^{t-1}}\max_{j\in\{1,\dots,t-1\}}(a_{j,i}^{k}-a_{t,i}^{k}), which measures the maximum accuracy loss when incorporating new tasks. Forgetting rate indicates the capability of resisting catastrophic forgetting.

Baselines. We compare our proposed FedMeS with other personalized FL and FCL baselines. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet FedAvg: A classical FL method which the server aggregates the models for all clients according to a weighted averaging of model parameters in each clients.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Ditto: A simple personalized FL method that utilizes a regularization term addressing the accuracy, robustness and fairness in FL while optimizing communication efficiency.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet FedRep: A personalized FL method that learns a divided model with global representation and personalized heads. Only the global representation is communicated between the server and clients, while each client adapts to its personalized head locally.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet FedAGEM: An FCL method that combines the conventional A-GEM method with FedAvg.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet FedWeIT: State-of-the-art FCL approach based on parameter isolation, which uses masks to divide the model parameter into base and task-adaptive parameters. The server averages the base parameters and broadcasts the task-adaptive parameters to all clients. Each client then trains all the task-adaptive parameters with the new taskâ€™s weights parameters based on a regularized objective.

Descriptions of Hyperparameters. For all the experiment, Adam optimizer is applied with adaptive learning rate which decay per round. Local sample batch size is 40. The participation rate(fraction) for the clients is set to 1. For Split CIFAR-100, Split EMINIST, Split CORe50 and Split MiniImageNet, 10 local epochs is performed in each communication round. And in Fusion Tasks-40, 5 local epochs is performed in each communication round. For each task a total of 10 communication rounds is performed. The regularization parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda in Ditto is set to 0.1. Number of memory samples in FedAGEM and proposed FedMeS is set to 150. The Î¸ksubscriptğœƒğ‘˜\theta_{k} in FedMeS is set to 0.5, and the number of nearest neighbours is set to 9.

All the experiments are conducted using PyTorch version 1.9 on a single machine equipped with two Intel Xeon 6226R CPUs, 384GB of memory, and four NVIDIA 3090 GPUs. Each experiment is repeated for 5 times. The averages and standard deviations of the above metrics are reported.

5.2 Cross-class Performance

We observe in TableÂ 1 that, for all cross-class datasets and number of clients, FedMeS outperforms all baselines in terms of average accuracy and forgetting rate. Notably, when compared to the state-of-the-art baseline FedWeIT, FedMeS achieves a performance boost of up to 102%percent102102\% in Split MiniImageNet. Additionally, FedMeS consistently outperforms FedWeIT in terms of forgetting rate, achieving a reduction of 4 to 6 times on the Split CORe50 dataset. Here FedWeIT experiences a significant decline in performance when applied to the Split MiniImageNet with ResNet-18. This is primarily due to its requirement of modifying the model structure to decompose the model parameters individually. Specifically, the downsample layers in ResNet-18 contain a relatively small number of essential parameters, and decomposing these layers negatively impacted the modelâ€™s accuracy. Additionally, the local inference process used in FedMeS has shown promising improvements (5%percent\% to 10%percent\% better performance in Aâ€‹câ€‹câ€‹_â€‹Aâ€‹Lâ€‹Lğ´ğ‘ğ‘_ğ´ğ¿ğ¿Acc\_ALL(Acc)), particularly when compared to FedMeS (noLIP).

Catastrophic forgetting. As shown in Fig.Â 3, FedMeS consistently achieves the highest accuracy and lowest forgetting rate, for all tasks under all settings. Catastrophic forgetting causes serious limitation for FedAvg and Ditto, as they do not incorporate previous task information in training. FedRep exhibits certain robustness against heterogeneity over clients. But without a designed mechanism to address catastrophic forgetting, it still subjects to gradual decay in average accuracy as new tasks arrive. The isolation method of FedWeIT to obtain adaptive weights on the clients cannot well maintain the knowledge from the previous tasks, resulting in a lower accuracy than FedMeS.

Client drift. As shown in Fig.Â 4, in all settings, FedMeS achieves the highest accuracy over all clients, thanks to its reliable personalization mechanism and local inference process. Also, FedMeS has the narrowest shaded area over all clients, indicating its ability to maintain consistent performance across all tasks for all clients. FedAGEM and FedWeIT fail to effectively address data heterogeneity, resulting in inferior model performance. FedWeIT relies on the stored knowledge of all tasks at the server, which may dilute the impact of individual tasks of each client.

Fig.Â 5 to Fig.Â 6 present the Aâ€‹câ€‹câ€‹_â€‹Tâ€‹aâ€‹sâ€‹kğ´ğ‘ğ‘_ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘˜Acc\_Task and Aâ€‹câ€‹câ€‹_â€‹Câ€‹lâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹nâ€‹tğ´ğ‘ğ‘_ğ¶ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘¡Acc\_Client for the Split EMINIST and Split CORe50 datasets. For every experiments FedMeS achieves highest Aâ€‹câ€‹câ€‹_â€‹Tâ€‹aâ€‹sâ€‹kğ´ğ‘ğ‘_ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘˜Acc\_Task and lowest forgetting rate, and for each client FedMeS achieves the best Aâ€‹câ€‹câ€‹_â€‹Câ€‹lâ€‹iâ€‹eâ€‹nâ€‹tğ´ğ‘ğ‘_ğ¶ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘¡Acc\_Client.

5.3 Cross-domain Performance

Fig.Â 7 shows the averaged test accuracy of each client across all tasks in the Fusion Tasks-40 dataset. The results indicate that the proposed FedMeS method outperforms the FedWeIT method, with higher average accuracy and lower forgetting rate among all clients and tasks. The poor performance of certain clients has a significant impact on other clients, and the isolation method employed by FedWeIT to mitigate catastrophic forgetting proves to be ineffective in the considered dataset with a large number of tasks. In contrast, the proposed FedMeS method achieves consistent performance across all tasks and clients, demonstrating its capability in scaling to large PFCL systems.

Effect of memory size. We observe in Fig.Â 8 (a) that FedMeS is memory efficient, such that with storing as small as 30 data samples in local memory, an accuracy of 48%percent4848\% can be achieved. As the memory size increases, the accuracy gradually improves, and persists around 55%percent5555\% after the memory size reaches 150 data samples. For heterogeneous memory sizes across different clients is shown in Fig.Â 9. As an instance, â€˜Here10-50â€™ denotes that every two clients are allocated memory samples spanning from 10 to 50, with a step of 10 samples, â€˜Fix50â€™ denotes a consistent allocation of 50 memory samples per client. Since each client is assigned with a unique task sequence, the memory sizes for each task is also heterogeneous. The Aâ€‹câ€‹câ€‹_â€‹Tâ€‹aâ€‹sâ€‹kğ´ğ‘ğ‘_ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘˜Acc\_Task boxplot reveals that FedMeS exhibits a broader accuracy range for each task under heterogeneous memory settings as opposed to fixed ones. Corroborating with Fig.Â 8, shown that performance in heterogeneous memory conditions is primarily influenced by the minimal memory sample size in each configuration. In terms of Aâ€‹câ€‹câ€‹_â€‹Aâ€‹Lâ€‹Lğ´ğ‘ğ‘_ğ´ğ¿ğ¿Acc\_ALL, it consistently surpasses other baselines from results in TableÂ 1, further showing the robustness of FedMeS under various conditions.

Communication and computation efficiency. We compare the communication and computation efficiency between FedMeS and FedWeIT in wall clock time, imposing a communication bandwidth limit of 40Mbps between the server and clients. The results, depicted in Fig.Â 8 (b), show that for all considered experiment settings, FedMeS outperforms FedWeIT by achieving higher accuracy using shorter execution time. This advantage becomes particularly prominent when experimenting with larger numbers of clients and tasks.

6 Conclusion

This paper has presented the challenges associated with catastrophic forgetting and client drift in PFCL and proposed the FedMeS framework as a solution to these issues. FedMeS levearges a small reference memory in the local training process to replay knowledge from previous tasks to alleviate forgetting; and the same memory is also used for the inference process by applying KNN-based Gaussian inference to further improve model personalization capability. We thoroughly analyzed the convergence behavior of FedMeS, and performed extensive experiments over various PFCL tasks. For all experiments, FedMeS uniformly outperforms existing techniques in terms of prediction accuracy and forgetting rate.

Appendix

Appendix A Detailed Theoretical Analysis

In this section, we give theoretical analysis on how our algorithm uses local memories and provide convergence proof of the local training process.

A.1 Reasoning of Local Continual Learning

In this section, we provide inference on how (2) can utilize memories of past tasks and how the update rule in (5) and (6) can solve the optimization problem.

To conduct continual learning in the centralized setting, [24] raises the concept of episodic memory, where for every task tğ‘¡t, a central memory â„³tsubscriptâ„³ğ‘¡\mathcal{M}_{t} is utilized to store examples sampled from task tğ‘¡t. Denote lâ€‹(hw;ğ’Ÿ)ğ‘™subscriptâ„ğ‘¤ğ’Ÿl(h_{w};\mathcal{D}) as the loss function hypothesis hwsubscriptâ„ğ‘¤h_{w} on dataset ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}, where hwsubscriptâ„ğ‘¤h_{w} is the hypothesis with parameter wğ‘¤w, and to avoid catastrophic forgetting, the authors raises that the loss of current model on previous tasks j=1,â€¦,tâˆ’1ğ‘—1â€¦ğ‘¡1j=1,...,t-1, i.e. lâ€‹(hw;â„³j)ğ‘™subscriptâ„ğ‘¤subscriptâ„³ğ‘—l(h_{w};\mathcal{M}_{j}) should not increase but decrease while minimizing loss on current task tğ‘¡t, i.e. lâ€‹(hw;ğ’Ÿt)ğ‘™subscriptâ„ğ‘¤superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡l(h_{w};\mathcal{D}^{t}), where ğ’Ÿtsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡\mathcal{D}^{t} is task tğ‘¡tâ€™s dataset. However, this method requires computing on all memory block â„³jsubscriptâ„³ğ‘—\mathcal{M}_{j} for every j<tğ‘—ğ‘¡j<t, which is computationally expensive.

Authors of [25], simplify the above decreasing constraint of losses on previous tasks into into an inequality constraint: by every training step the average memory loss over the previous tasks does not increase. Formally speaking, while learning task tğ‘¡t, the objective is,

Under this circumstance, the local update ensures the optimization both on the current task and local memories. As a result, the communication to the central server would not impede the local memories, and the regularization term Î»ğœ†\lambda could be added to interpolate the global model and the local model, which turns into (5).

Above is how the clients use local memory data to strengthen the personalized continual learning in PFCL.

Discussions.
